shortDescription: Easily implement human review of ML predictions
detailDescription: Amazon Augmented AI (Amazon A2I) enables you to build the workflows required for human review of ML predictions. Amazon A2I brings human review to all developers, removing the undifferentiated heavy lifting associated with building human review systems or managing large numbers of human reviewers.

items.name: Developer Guide
items.description: Provides a conceptual overview of Amazon A2I. Offers step-by-step instructions for using AI applications such as Amazon Rekognition, Amazon Textract, or your custom machine learning (ML) models to create workflows required for human review of ML predictions.

items.name: Amazon A2I Runtime Model
items.description: This API reference includes information about API actions and data types that you can use to interact with Amazon A2I programmatically.

items.name: Using Amazon A2I with Amazon Textract
items.description: Provides step-by-step instructions for using Amazon A2I with Amazon Textract.

items.name: Reviewing Unsafe Content with Amazon A2I Using Amazon Rekognition
items.description: Provides step-by-step instructions for using Amazon A2I with Amazon Rekognition.

items.name: Crowd HTML Elements Reference
items.description: Use HTML elements to create custom worker user interfaces (UIs) for your human review workflows.

items.name: Sample Task User Interfaces (UIs)
items.description: A GitHub repository of example task UIs built using HTML crowd elements.

items.name: Jupyter Notebook Demos
items.description: A GitHub repository of example Jupyter Notebooks that demonstrate how to integrate Amazon A2I in machine learning workflows.

detailDescription: Amazon API Gateway enables you to create and deploy your own REST and WebSocket APIs at any scale. You can create robust, secure, and scalable APIs that access Amazon Web Services or other web services, as well as data that’s stored in the AWS Cloud. You can create APIs to use in your own client applications, or you can make your APIs available to third-party app developers.

items.name: Developer Guide
items.description: Provides a conceptual overview of Amazon API Gateway and includes detailed instructions for using the service.

items.name: REST API Reference
items.description: Describes the API Gateway API operations for creating and deploying REST APIs.

items.name: HTTP and WebSocket API Reference
items.description: Describes the API Gateway API operations for creating and deploying HTTP and WebSocket APIs.

items.name: REST API CLI Reference
items.description: Describes the API Gateway commands for creating and deploying REST APIs using the AWS CLI. Provides syntax, options, and usage examples for each command.

items.name: HTTP and WebSocket API CLI Reference
items.description: Describes the API Gateway commands for creating and deploying HTTP and WebSocket APIs using the AWS CLI. Provides syntax, options, and usage examples for each command.

shortDescription: No-code integration for SaaS apps and AWS services
detailDescription: Amazon AppFlow is a fully managed API integration service that you use to connect your software as a service (SaaS) applications to AWS services, and securely transfer data. Use Amazon AppFlow flows to manage and automate your data transfers without needing to write code.

items.name: User Guide
items.description: Describes key concepts and provides instructions for using Amazon AppFlow.

items.name: API Reference
items.description: Describes all the API operations for Amazon AppFlow in detail. Also provides sample requests, responses, and errors for the supported web service protocols.

items.name: Amazon AppFlow in the AWS CLI
items.description: Describes the Amazon AppFlow operations that are available in the AWS Command Line Interface (AWS CLI).

items.name: Amazon AppFlow in the AWS CloudFormation User Guide
items.description: Describes all Amazon AppFlow resource and property types that are supported by AWS CloudFormation.

items.name: Amazon AppFlow in the AWS SDK for Python (Boto3)
items.description: Describes all of the Amazon AppFlow operations that are included in the AWS SDK for Python (Boto3).

items.name: Amazon AppFlow in the AWS SDK for Java 2.x
items.description: Describes all of the Amazon AppFlow operations that are included the AWS SDK for Java 2.x.

items.name: Amazon AppFlow Custom Connector SDK (Python)
items.description: Use the Python Custom Connector SDK to build custom source and destination connectors for Amazon AppFlow. With custom connectors, you can transfer data between private APIs, on-premise systems, other cloud services, and AWS.

items.name: Amazon AppFlow Custom Connector SDK (Java)
items.description: Use the Java Custom Connector SDK to build custom source and destination connectors for Amazon AppFlow. With custom connectors, you can transfer data between private APIs, on-premise systems, other cloud services, and AWS.

shortDescription: Move traffic for application disaster recovery
detailDescription: Amazon Application Recovery Controller (ARC) (ARC) gives you insights about whether your applications and resources are ready for recovery, and helps you move traffic across AWS Regions or away from Availability Zones for application disaster recovery.

items.name: Developer Guide
items.description: Provides a conceptual overview of Amazon Application Recovery Controller (ARC) and includes detailed instructions for using the various features.

items.name: Zonal Shift and Zonal Autoshift API Reference
items.description: Describes all the API operations for zonal shift and zonal autoshift in ARC. Also provides sample requests, responses, and errors for the supported web services protocols.

items.name: Recovery Readiness API Reference
items.description: Describes all the API operations for recovery readiness in ARC. Also provides sample requests, responses, and errors for the supported web services protocols.

items.name: Recovery Control Configuration API Reference
items.description: Describes all the API operations for configuring recovery control in ARC. Also provides sample requests, responses, and errors for the supported web services protocols.

items.name: Routing Control API Reference
items.description: Describes all the API operations for routing controls in ARC. Also provides sample requests, responses, and errors for the supported web services protocols.

items.name: Zonal Shift in the AWS CLI Reference
items.description: Describes the commands in the AWS CLI that you can use to move traffic away from an Availability Zone using a zonal shift in ARC. Provides syntax, options, and usage examples for each command.

items.name: Recovery Readiness in the AWS CLI Reference
items.description: Describes the commands in the AWS CLI that you can use to configure recovery readiness in ARC. Provides syntax, options, and usage examples for each command.

items.name: Recovery Control Configuration in the AWS CLI Reference
items.description: Describes the commands in the AWS CLI that you can use to configure recovery control in ARC. Provides syntax, options, and usage examples for each command.

items.name: Routing Control in the AWS CLI Reference
items.description: Describes the commands in the AWS CLI that you can use with routing control states in ARC. Provides syntax, options, and usage examples for each command.

shortDescription: Stream desktop applications securely to a browser
detailDescription: Amazon AppStream 2.0 is a fully managed, secure application streaming service that lets you stream desktop applications to users without rewriting applications. AppStream 2.0 provides users with instant access to the applications that they need with a responsive, fluid user experience on the device of their choice.

items.name: Administration Guide
items.description: Provides a conceptual overview of AppStream 2.0 and includes detailed instructions for using the features available in this service.

items.name: API Reference
items.description: Describes all the API operations for AppStream 2.0 in detail. Also provides sample requests, responses, and errors for the supported web services protocols.

items.name: AppStream 2.0 section in the AWS CLI Reference
items.description: Describes the AppStream 2.0 commands that are available in the AWS Command Line Interface (AWS CLI).

items.name: Extension SDK Developer Guide
items.description: Describes how to get started with the Amazon DCV Extension SDK that is supported by AppStream 2.0 and provides an SDK reference.

shortDescription: Query data in Amazon S3 using SQL
detailDescription: Amazon Athena is an interactive query service that makes it easy to analyze data in Amazon S3 using standard SQL. Athena is serverless, so there is no infrastructure to setup or manage, and you pay only for the queries you run. To get started, simply point to your data in S3, define the schema, and start querying using standard SQL.

items.name: User Guide
items.description: Learn how to use Athena to query data stored in Amazon S3.

items.name: API Reference
items.description: Describes the Athena API operations in detail.

shortDescription: High performance managed relational database engine
detailDescription: Amazon Relational Database Service (Amazon RDS) is a web service that makes it easier to set up, operate, and scale a relational database in the cloud. It provides cost-efficient, resizeable capacity for an industry-standard relational database and manages common database administration tasks. Amazon Aurora is a fully managed relational database engine that's built for the cloud and compatible with MySQL and PostgreSQL. Amazon Aurora is part of Amazon RDS.

items.name: Amazon RDS User Guide
items.description: Describes all Amazon RDS concepts and provides instructions on using the various features with both the console and the command line interface.

items.name: Amazon Aurora User Guide
items.description: Describes all Amazon Aurora concepts and provides instructions on using the various features with both the console and the command line interface.

items.name: Amazon Aurora DSQL User Guide
items.description: Describes all Amazon Aurora DSQL concepts and provides instructions on using the various features.

items.name: Amazon RDS Getting Started Guide
items.description: Introduces Amazon RDS and walks you through setting up, securing, managing, and connecting to your first DB instance.

items.name: Amazon RDS in the AWS CLI Reference
items.description: Describes all the CLI commands for Amazon RDS in detail. Provides all syntax. Also provides examples for the most common commands.

items.name: Performance Insights in the AWS CLI Reference
items.description: Describes all the CLI commands for Amazon RDS Performance Insights in detail. Provides all syntax. Also provides examples for the most common commands.

items.name: RDS Data API in the AWS CLI Reference
items.description: Describes all the CLI commands for RDS Data API in detail. Provides all syntax.

items.name: Amazon RDS API Reference
items.description: Describes all the API operations for Amazon RDS in detail. Also provides sample requests, responses, and errors for the supported web services protocols.

items.name: Performance Insights API Reference
items.description: Describes all the API operations for Performance Insights in detail. Also provides sample requests, responses, and errors for the supported web service protocols.

items.name: RDS Data API Reference
items.description: Describes all operations for RDS Data API in detail. Also provides sample requests, responses, and errors for the supported web service protocols.

items.name: Amazon RDS for Oracle Release Notes
items.description: Describes the Oracle Database versions that are supported by Amazon RDS.

items.name: Amazon RDS for PostgreSQL Release Notes
items.description: Describes the PostgreSQL versions and extensions that are supported by Amazon RDS.

items.name: Release Notes for Aurora MySQL
items.description: Describes the Aurora MySQL versions that are supported by Amazon Aurora.

items.name: Release Notes for Aurora PostgreSQL
items.description: Describes the Aurora PostgreSQL versions and extensions that are supported by Amazon Aurora.

items.name: Architecture Center: Best Practices for Databases
items.description: Find best practices for choosing the right AWS database service, migrating your database, and managing database services.

shortDescription: Fastest serverless distributed SQL database for always available applications
detailDescription: Amazon Aurora DSQL is a serverless distributed SQL database with virtually unlimited scale, high availability, and zero infrastructure management. Aurora DSQL offers fast distributed SQL reads and writes with optimal price performance. You can use Aurora DSQL to scale to meet any workload demand without database sharding or instance upgrades. With its active-active distributed architecture, Aurora DSQL ensures strong data consistency designed for 99.99% single-Region and 99.999% multi-Region availability. The serverless design removes the operational burden of patching, upgrades, and maintenance downtime. Aurora DSQL is PostgreSQL compatible, and provides an easy-to-use developer experience.

items.name: Getting started with Amazon Aurora DSQL
items.description: Learn how to get started with Aurora DSQL by creating a cluster and running some SQL queries.

items.name: Developer Guide
items.description: Describes all Amazon Aurora DSQL concepts and provides instructions on using the various features.

items.name: API Reference
items.description: Describes in detail all the API operations for Amazon Aurora DSQL.

shortDescription: Access best-in-class foundation models to build generative AI applications
detailDescription: Amazon Bedrock is a fully managed service that makes it easy to use foundation models from third-party providers and Amazon.

items.name: Get started with Amazon Bedrock
items.description: Get started with the Amazon Bedrock console and API.

items.name: Get started with Amazon Nova
items.description: Get started with the Amazon Nova console and API.

items.name: Code examples

items.name: Batch inference

items.description: Import foundation models that you have customized in other environments.

items.name: Prompt routing
items.description: Efficiently route requests between different foundational models within the same model family.

items.name: Agents
items.description: Build and configure autonomous agents in your application.

items.name: Flows
items.description: Connect Amazon Bedrock features and other AWS services to create generative AI workflows.

items.name: Knowledge bases
items.description: Improve model responses by using Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) with your data.

items.name: Prompt management
items.description: Create reusable prompts for your applications.

items.name: Guardrails
items.description: Implement application-specific safeguards based on your use cases and responsible AI policies.

items.name: Data automation
items.description: Extract valuable insights from unstructured content.

items.name: Security
items.description: Configure Amazon Bedrock to meet your security and compliance objectives.

items.description: Grant users permission to perform actions on Amazon Bedrock with IAM policies.

items.name: AWS managed policies
items.description: Grant users permission to perform actions on Amazon Bedrock with IAM policies.

items.name: AWS service roles
items.description: Use IAM service roles for some features to let Amazon Bedrock carry out tasks on your behalf.

Amazon Bedrock in Amazon
              SageMaker Unified Studio

items.name: Responsible AI
items.description: Transform responsible AI from theory into practice.

items.name: Amazon Bedrock re:Post Forum
items.description: Find crowd-sourced, expert-reviewed answers to your Amazon Bedrock questions.

items.name: Amazon Bedrock product page
items.description: Get more information about Amazon Bedrock.

detailDescription: Amazon Braket is a fully managed service that helps you get started with quantum computing by providing a development environment to explore and design quantum algorithms, test them on simulated quantum computers, and run them on your choice of different quantum hardware technologies.

items.name: Developer Guide
items.description: Provides a conceptual overview of Amazon Braket, and detailed information about how to design and create quantum tasks, test them on quantum simulators, and then run them on a quantum computer.

items.name: API Reference
items.description: The Amazon Braket API Reference provides information about the operations and structures supported by Amazon Braket.

items.name: Amazon Braket Boto 3 SDK
items.description: Allows you to interact with Amazon Braket using the AWS SDK for Python (Boto3).

items.name: Braket Open Source
items.description: The Amazon Braket GitHub organization provides a good starting point to discover multiple frameworks and educational content. The material is open sourced and builds on top of Amazon Braket.

shortDescription: Frustration-free meetings, video calls, and chat
detailDescription: Amazon Chime is a secure, real-time, unified communications service that transforms meetings by making them more efficient and easier to conduct.

items.name: Administrator Guide
items.description: Helps you use Amazon Chime to perform several administrative tasks, such as creating an Amazon Chime account, inviting users, and managing licenses.

items.name: User Guide
items.description: Helps you use Amazon Chime, including joining, attending, and scheduling meetings for your organization.

items.name: API Reference
items.description: Describes the API operations for Amazon Chime.

items.name: Amazon Chime section of AWS CLI Reference
items.description: Documents the Amazon Chime commands available in the AWS Command Line Interface (AWS CLI).

shortDescription: Store hundreds of millions of application-specific objects
detailDescription: Amazon Cloud Directory is a cloud-native directory that can store hundreds of millions of application-specific objects with multiple relationships and schemas. Use Cloud Directory when you need a cloud-scale directory to share and control access to hierarchical data between your applications. With Cloud Directory, you can organize application data into multiple hierarchies to support many organizational pivots and relationships across directory information.

items.name: Developer Guide
items.description: Describes how to create and manage an Amazon Cloud Directory schema and directory for use with your website or application. Also provides instructions for using the various features through the AWS Directory Service console.

items.name: API Reference
items.description: Describes the API operations for Amazon Cloud Directory.

items.name: Amazon Cloud Directory in the AWS CLI Reference
items.description: Describes the Cloud Directory commands in the AWS Command Line Interface.

detailDescription: Amazon CloudFront speeds up distribution of your static and dynamic web content, such as .html, .css, .php, image, and media files. When users request your content, CloudFront delivers it through a worldwide network of edge locations that provide low latency and high performance.

items.name: Developer Guide
items.description: Provides an overview of Amazon CloudFront, detailed feature descriptions, procedures for using the console, and an explanation of the API.

items.name: API Reference
items.description: Describes all the API operations for Amazon CloudFront in detail. Also provides sample requests, responses, and errors for the supported web services protocols.

detailDescription: Amazon CloudSearch is a fully managed service in the cloud that makes it easy to set up, manage, and scale a search solution for your website. Amazon CloudSearch enables you to search large collections of data such as web pages, document files, forum posts, or product information. With Amazon CloudSearch, you can quickly add search capabilities to your website without having to become a search expert or worry about hardware provisioning, setup, and maintenance. As your volume of data and traffic fluctuates, Amazon CloudSearch automatically scales to meet your needs.

items.name: Developer Guide
items.description: Describes how to create, manage, and use an Amazon CloudSearch domain to implement a search solution for your website or application. Also provides instructions for using the various features through the AWS Management Console, CLI, and API.

detailDescription: Amazon CloudWatch provides a reliable, scalable, and flexible monitoring solution that you can start using within minutes. You no longer need to set up, manage, and scale your own monitoring systems and infrastructure.

items.name: CloudWatch User Guide
items.description: Provides a conceptual overview of CloudWatch and includes detailed development instructions for using the various features.

items.name: CloudWatch API Reference
items.description: Describes all the API operations for CloudWatch in detail. Also provides sample requests, responses, and errors for the supported web services protocols.

items.name: CloudWatch Application Insights section of the AWS CLI Reference
items.description: Describes the CloudWatch commands in the AWS CLI that you can use to detect common problems with your applications. Provides syntax, options, and usage examples for each command.

items.name: CloudWatch Synthetics section of the AWS CLI Reference
items.description: Describes the CloudWatch Synthetics commands in the AWS CLI that you can use to create and manage canaries. Provides syntax, options, and usage examples for each command.

items.name: CloudWatch CLI Reference
items.description: Describes the CloudWatch CLI commands that you can use to monitor AWS. Provides syntax, options, and usage examples for each command.

items.description: Provides a conceptual overview of CloudWatch Logs and includes detailed development instructions for using the various features.

items.name: CloudWatch Logs API Reference

items.name: CloudWatch Logs section of the AWS CLI Reference
items.description: Describes the AWS CLI commands that you can use to administer CloudWatch Logs. Provides syntax, options, and usage examples for each command.

sections.name: Amazon CloudWatch Events is now Amazon EventBridge

items.description: Provides a conceptual overview of EventBridge and includes detailed development instructions for using the various features.

items.name: EventBridge API Reference
items.description: Describes all the API operations for EventBridge in detail. Also provides sample requests, responses, and errors for the supported web services protocols.

items.name: EventBridge section of the AWS CLI Reference
items.description: Describes the AWS CLI commands that you can use to administer EventBridge. Provides syntax, options, and usage examples for each command.

shortDescription: Unified software development service to develop and deliver on AWS
detailDescription: Amazon CodeCatalyst is a cloud-based collaboration space for software development teams. CodeCatalyst provides one place where you can plan work, collaborate on code, and build, test, and deploy applications with continuous integration/continuous delivery (CI/CD) tools.

items.name: User Guide
items.description: Learn how to use Amazon CodeCatalyst to track work, develop code, and build, test, and deploy your applications.

items.name: API Reference
items.description: Describes API operations for Amazon CodeCatalyst in detail. Also provides details of request and response syntax and errors for the supported web services protocols.

items.name: Administrator Guide
items.description: Learn how to set up an Amazon CodeCatalyst space where users can collaborate on projects. Find out how to view your billing information and upgrade your subscription.

items.name: Blueprints Resources
items.description: Learn how to use blueprints to create new projects or apply them to existing projects. Also learn how to develop custom blueprints for your spaces. The open-source GitHub repository provides access to the blueprints SDK and sample blueprints.

items.name: Action Developer Guide
items.description: Learn how to create custom actions for your workflows using the Amazon CodeCatalyst Action Developer Guide.

items.name: Set up Support for Amazon CodeCatalyst
items.description: Learn how administrators can set up the support plan and roles required to create and manage support cases for their CodeCatalyst space. Once configured, space and project members can create support cases through Support for Amazon CodeCatalyst.

items.name: Additional Resources
items.description: Learn more about how to use Amazon CodeCatalyst, common questions, and how to get help from the community when using CodeCatalyst.

shortDescription: Find your most expensive lines of code
detailDescription: CodeGuru provides intelligent recommendations for improving application performance, efficiency, security, and code quality.

items.name: User Guide
items.description: Provides a conceptual overview of Amazon CodeGuru Security, instructions for getting started, product and service integrations, and creating and understanding code scans.

items.name: API Reference
items.description: Describes all the Amazon CodeGuru Security API operations in detail. Also provides sample requests, responses, and errors for the supported web services protocols.

items.name: CodeGuru Security section of the AWS CLI Reference

items.name: Detector Library
items.description: Lists all detectors that Amazon CodeGuru Security uses to analyze code. Provides detailed information about the detectors, their impact on applications, and ways to mitigate risk.

items.name: User Guide

items.name: CodeGuru Profiler section of the AWS CLI Reference
items.description: Describes the AWS CLI commands that you can use to work with profiling groups.

items.name: User Guide

items.name: CodeGuru Reviewer section of the AWS CLI Reference
items.description: Describes the AWS CLI commands that you can use to work with CodeGuru Reviewer repository associations and code reviews.

items.name: User Guide
items.description: Describes how to create and participate in a competitive AWS BugBust event that incentivizes fixing bugs and optimizing profiling groups by a development team.

detailDescription: Amazon Cognito handles user authentication and authorization for your web and mobile apps. With user pools, you can easily and securely add sign-up and sign-in functionality to your apps. With identity pools (federated identities), your apps can get temporary credentials that grant users access to specific AWS resources, whether the users are anonymous or are signed in.

items.name: Developer Guide
items.description: Provides a conceptual overview of Amazon Cognito user pools and includes instructions that show you how to use its features.

items.name: API Reference
items.description: Describes the REST API for user pools.

items.name: API Reference
items.description: Describes the REST API for identity pools.

items.name: AWS CLI Reference
items.description: Describes the AWS CLI commands for identity pools.

items.description: Describes the REST API for Amazon Cognito Sync.
